title: How to Find the Greatest Common Divisor of Two Integers

steps.title: Know your vocabulary:
steps.content: Know your vocabulary: when you divide 32 by 5, [2] X Research source 32 is the dividend 5 is the divisor 6 is the quotient 2 is the remainder (or modulo).

steps.title: Identify the larger of the two numbers.
steps.content: Identify the larger of the two numbers. That will be the dividend, and the smaller the divisor. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Write out this algorithm:
steps.content: Write out this algorithm: (dividend) = (divisor) * (quotient) + (remainder) [4] X Research source

steps.title: Put the larger number in the spot for dividend, and the smaller number as the divisor.
steps.content: Put the larger number in the spot for dividend, and the smaller number as the divisor. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Decide how many times the smaller number will divide into the larger number, and drop it into the algorithm as the quotient.
steps.content: Decide how many times the smaller number will divide into the larger number, and drop it into the algorithm as the quotient.

steps.title: Calculate the remainder, and substitute it into the appropriate place in the algorithm.
steps.content: Calculate the remainder, and substitute it into the appropriate place in the algorithm. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Write out the algorithm again, but this time A) use the old divisor as the new dividend and B) use the remainder as the new divisor.
steps.content: Write out the algorithm again, but this time A) use the old divisor as the new dividend and B) use the remainder as the new divisor.

steps.title: Repeat the previous step until the remainder is zero.
steps.content: Repeat the previous step until the remainder is zero.

steps.title: The last divisor is the greatest common divisor.
steps.content: The last divisor is the greatest common divisor.

steps.title: Here is an example, where we are trying to find the GCD of 108 and 30:
steps.content: Here is an example, where we are trying to find the GCD of 108 and 30:

steps.title: Notice how the 30 and the 18 in the first line shift positions to create the second line.
steps.content: Notice how the 30 and the 18 in the first line shift positions to create the second line. Then, the 18 and 12 shift to create the third line, and the 12 and 6 shift to create the fourth line. The 3, 1, 1, and 2 that follow the multiplication symbol do not reappear. They represent how many times the divisor goes into the dividend, so they are unique to each line.

steps.title: Drop any negative signs.
steps.content: Drop any negative signs. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Find the prime factorization
steps.content: Find the prime factorization of the numbers, and list them out as shown. [8] X Research source Using 24 and 18 as the example numbers: 24- 2 x 2 x 2 x 3 18- 2 x 3 x 3 Using 50 and 35 as the example numbers: 50- 2 x 5 x 5 35- 5 x 7

steps.title: Identify all common prime factors.
steps.content: Identify all common prime factors. Using 24 and 18 as the example numbers: 24- 2 x 2 x 2 x 3 18- 2 x 3 x 3 Using 50 and 35 as the example numbers: 50- 2 x 5 x 5 35- 5 x 7

steps.title: Multiply
steps.content: Multiply the common factors together. [9] X Research source In the case of 24 and 18, multiply 2 and 3 together to get 6 . Six is the greatest common factor of 24 and 18. In the case of 50 and 35, there is nothing to multiply. 5 is the only common factor, and therefore the greatest.
